3. Saul, &c. Luke returneth again to describe the persecution of the faithful of the church of Jerusalem, as if he should have said, In so great outrageousness of the bloody Jews against the church of Christ, Saul did more waste it than the rest: for having received power from the Sanhedrim, not only when the saints were put to death by him did he give his voice against them, but also he, entering into every house, and hailing thence both men and women, did bind them and commit them into prison, and did beat them often through all synagogues, and so for fear he forced some to blaspheme by denying Christ 3 he persecuted others, con- stant in the faith, to death. So cruel and furious is the vehemency of the zeal which is not according to knowledge. See below,
